name.text: 28.3.4.14 Spherical polar coordinates div of curl of F

questiontext.text:
For \(\underline{F} = {@aa@}r^{2}\cos heta\underline{\hat{r}} + {@aa@}\cos\phi \underline{\hat{ heta}}\), find \(\underline{ abla} \cdot (\underline{ abla} imes \underline{F})\).

In your answer, type \( heta\), \(\phi\), \(\sin(x)\), and \(cos(x)\) as theta, phi, sin(x), cos(x) respectively.

\(\underline{ abla} \cdot (\underline{ abla} imes \underline{F}) =\)[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
We know that \(\underline{F} = {@aa@}r^{2}\cos\theta\underline{\hat{r}} + {@aa@}\cos\phi \underline{\hat{\theta}}\), and aim to find \(\underline{\nabla} \cdot (\underline{\nabla} \times \underline{F})\). We start first by finding \(\underline{\nabla} \times \underline{F}\):

\[\begin{aligned} \underline{\nabla} \times \underline{F} &= \frac{1}{r^2\sin\theta}\begin{vmatrix} \hat{\underline{r}} & r\hat{\underline{\theta}} & r\sin\theta\hat{\underline{\phi}} \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial r} & \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta} & \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi}\\ F_r & rF_\theta & r\sin\theta F_\phi \end{vmatrix}\\ &= \frac{1}{r^2\sin\theta}\begin{vmatrix} \hat{\underline{r}} & r\hat{\underline{\theta}} & r\sin\theta\hat{\underline{\phi}} \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial r} & \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta} & \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi}\\ {@aa@}r^2\cos\theta & {@aa@}r\cos\phi & 0 \end{vmatrix}\\ &= \frac{1}{r^2\sin\theta} \left[ \hat{\underline{r}}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial \theta}(0) - \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi}( {@aa@}r\cos\phi)\right) -r\hat{\underline{\theta}}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial r}(0) - \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi}({@aa@}r^2\cos\theta) \right) +r\sin\theta\hat{\underline{\phi}}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial r}({@aa@}r\cos\phi) - \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta}({@aa@}r^2\cos\theta) \right) \right] \\ &=\frac{1}{r^2\sin\theta} \left[ {@aa@}r\sin\phi\hat{\underline{r}} + r\sin\theta\hat{\underline{\phi}}({@aa@}\cos\phi+{@aa@}r^2\sin\theta) \right]\\ &=\frac{{@aa@}}{r}\sin\phi\csc\theta\hat{\underline{r}} + \left(\frac{{@aa@}}{r}\cos\phi+{@aa@}r\sin\theta)\right)\hat{\underline{\phi}}\\ \\ \underline{\nabla} \cdot (\underline{\nabla} \times \underline{F}) &=\underline{\nabla} \cdot (\frac{{@aa@}}{r}\sin\phi\csc\theta\hat{\underline{r}} + \left(\frac{{@aa@}}{r}\cos\phi+{@aa@}r\sin\theta)\right)\hat{\underline{\phi}})\\ &= \frac{1}{r^2\sin\theta}\left[\frac{\partial}{\partial r}({@aa@}r\sin\phi) + \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta}(0) + \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi}({@aa@}\cos\phi+{@aa@}r^2\sin\theta)\right] \\ &= \frac{1}{r^2\sin\theta}\left[{@aa@}\sin\phi-{@aa@}\sin\phi\right] \\ &= 0 \end{aligned}\]

It is worthy of note that more generally speaking, for any vector field \(\underline{G}\), \(\underline{\nabla} \cdot (\underline{\nabla} \times \underline{G}) = 0\) is always true.
